questions.experimentContext: Available resources: Patient-derived nasal epithelial cells and intestinal organoids (both carrying the c.3718-2477C>T mutation homozygously), 2'-MOE phosphorothioate ASOs designed to mask the cryptic splice sites, RT-PCR and RT-qPCR equipment, Western blot apparatus, an Ussing chamber for transepithelial ion transport measurement, a forskolin-induced swelling (FIS) assay for organoids, scrambled sequence ASO control, dose range of ASO (1-1000 nM), and a time course capability (24-96 hours post-treatment).
options: Transfect patient-derived nasal cells with the ASO at a single concentration (100 nM), extract RNA at 48 hours, perform RT-PCR with primers flanking the cryptic exon to assess exon skipping, and declare success if any correctly spliced product is detected on an agarose gel
Perform whole-genome sequencing of ASO-treated cells to confirm the ASO has permanently corrected the intronic mutation at the DNA level, restoring the wild-type CFTR sequence

Treat patient nasal cells and intestinal organoids with ASO at multiple concentrations (1, 10, 100, 500, 1000 nM) and scrambled control, then perform a multi-level assessment: (1) RT-PCR with primers flanking intron 22 to visualize the shift from cryptic exon-including to correctly spliced transcript, quantified by RT-qPCR for the ratio of correct/aberrant transcripts across the dose range; (2) Western blot for CFTR protein to confirm restoration of full-length CFTR production; (3) Ussing chamber measurement of CFTR-dependent chloride current (short-circuit current after forskolin stimulation followed by CFTR inhibitor-172) in nasal cell monolayers to demonstrate functional channel rescue; (4) forskolin-induced swelling assay in intestinal organoids as an independent functional readout; include dose-response curves for each readout and a scrambled ASO control at each concentration to exclude non-specific effects

Treat cells with the ASO and measure total cellular chloride concentration by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) as the sole readout, since CFTR dysfunction alters total cellular chloride content
questions.explanation: This comprehensive experimental design addresses all four levels of therapeutic ASO validation: RNA splicing, protein expression, channel function, and physiological readout. (1) RT-PCR/RT-qPCR for splicing: Primers flanking the cryptic exon in intron 22 will amplify two products — a longer band including the cryptic exon (aberrant) and a shorter band without it (correct). The dose-response relationship reveals the ASO concentration needed for effective exon skipping. RT-qPCR with junction-specific primers provides quantitative assessment. The scrambled control is essential to exclude non-specific effects of phosphorothioate chemistry (which can bind proteins non-specifically and activate innate immune sensors like TLR7/8). (2) Western blot for CFTR: Splicing correction should restore full-length CFTR protein (~168 kDa). The cryptic exon introduces a PTC that triggers NMD, so untreated cells produce little/no CFTR protein. Detection of band C (fully glycosylated, mature CFTR) indicates proper protein folding and trafficking to the plasma membrane. (3) Ussing chamber electrophysiology: This is the gold standard for CFTR function. Differentiated nasal epithelial monolayers on permeable supports are mounted in Ussing chambers. Forskolin activates CFTR via cAMP/PKA, producing a chloride secretory current (increase in short-circuit current, Isc). Application of CFTRinh-172 specifically inhibits CFTR, confirming the current is CFTR-dependent. The magnitude of forskolin-stimulated, CFTRinh-172-sensitive current quantifies functional rescue. (4) Forskolin-induced swelling (FIS) assay: Patient-derived intestinal organoids swell when CFTR is functional (forskolin activates CFTR-dependent fluid secretion into the organoid lumen). The area under the curve of swelling normalized to baseline is a validated, quantitative biomarker that correlates with clinical severity and drug response. This provides an independent, physiologically relevant confirmation in a second tissue type. Option A is inadequate — single concentration, single time point, qualitative gel assessment, no protein or functional readout. Option C is wrong — ASOs do not edit DNA; they work at the RNA level by sterically blocking splice site recognition. Option D measures the wrong parameter — total cellular chloride is not a direct readout of CFTR channel activity.
